contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox album | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Albums --> | Name = Verities & Balderdash | Type = [[Album]] | Artist = [[Harry Chapin]] | Cover = Harry_Chapin_-_Verities_&_Balderdash.jpg|Album cover | Released = August 24, 1974 | Recorded = 1973, [[Connecticut Recording Studios]]<br/>[[Bridgeport, Connecticut]] | Genre = [[Folk rock]] | Length = 43:49 | Label = [[Elektra Records|Elektra]]<br/>7E-1012 | Producer = [[Paul Leka]] | Last album =''[[Short Stories (Harry Chapin album)|Short Stories]]'' <br/> (1973) | This album ='''''Verities & Balderdash''''' <br/> (1974) | Next album =''[[Portrait Gallery (Harry Chapin Album)|Portrait Gallery]]'' <br/> (1975) }} {{Album ratings |rev1 = [[Allmusic]] |rev1score = {{Rating|4.5|5}}<ref>[{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r3622|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic review]</ref> }}<!-- Automatically generated by DASHBot--> '''''Verities & Balderdash''''' is the fourth studio album by the American singer/songwriter [[Harry Chapin]], released in 1974. (see [[1974 in music]]). "[[Cat's in the Cradle]]" was Chapin's highest charting single, finishing at #44 for the year on the 1974 Billboard year-end Hot 100 chart. The follow-up single, "I Wanna Learn a Love Song," barely entered the Billboard Hot 100 Singles Chart. A third single, "What Made America Famous?", failed to chart. The album was certified gold on December 17, 1974.<ref>[http://www.superseventies.com/spchapinharry2.html SuperSeventies.com] Verities & Balderdash</ref> The album was advertised with the slogan: "As only Harry can tell it." <ref>[http://www.anyoldkindofday.com/album_VeritiesandBalderdash.html http://www.anyoldkindofday.com/album_VeritiesandBalderdash.html]</ref> The album was the first and only work by Chapin to exclusively use professional studio musicians, rather than his touring band, as had been the case in previous projects. ==Track listing== ===Side One=== #"[[Cat's in the Cradle]]" (Sandy Chapin, Harry Chapin) – 3:44 #"I Wanna Learn a Love Song" (Harry Chapin) – 4:19 #"Shooting Star" (Harry Chapin) – 4:02 #"[[30,000 Pounds of Bananas]]" (Harry Chapin) – 5:45 #"She Sings Songs Without Words" (Harry Chapin) – 3:31 <ref>Original LP 1974 Elektra/Asylum/Nonesuch Records 7E-1012</ref> ===Side Two=== #"What Made America Famous?" (Harry Chapin) – 6:53 #"Vacancy" (Harry Chapin) – 4:00 #"Halfway to Heaven" (Harry Chapin) – 6:10 #"[[Six String Orchestra]]" (Harry Chapin) – 5:25 <ref>Original LP 1974 Elektra/Asylum/Nonesuch Records 7E-1012</ref> == Personnel== '''Band''' *Harry Chapin - [[guitar]], [[vocals]] *[[John Tropea]] - [[acoustic guitar]], [[sitar]] *Don Payne - [[Bass guitar|bass]] *[[Allan Schwartzberg]] - [[drums]] *[[Don Grolnick]] - [[piano]], [[electric piano]], [[harpsichord]] *Ron Bacchiocchi - [[synthesizer]] *Irving Spice - concertmaster *George Simms - background vocals *[[Frank Simms]] - background vocals *Dave Kondziela - background vocals *Zizi Roberts - female vocals '''Production''' *Ron Bacchiocchi - recording engineer *Paul Leka - mixing *Fred Kewley - mixing *Glen Christensen - art direction *Bill Hofman - illustration *Ruth Bernal - photography *Shiah Grumet - design ==References== <references/> {{Harry Chapin}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Verities and Balderdash}} [[Category:Harry Chapin albums]] [[Category:1974 albums]] [[Category:Albums produced by Paul Leka]] [[Category:Elektra Records albums]]
